Speaker: louis
Dialogue: So...what do you think?

Speaker: rachel
Dialogue: It's gorgeous!

Speaker: ellie
Dialogue: Am I really gonna have my own room?

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: ellie
Dialogue: Yaay!

Speaker: rachel
Dialogue: Yes, but the rope might be--

Speaker: ellie
Dialogue: Yaay!

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: Let her go. It's cool.

Speaker: rachel
Dialogue: Louis, the house is beautiful.

Speaker: rachel
Dialogue: The Master of Disaster awakes.

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: And Buckaroo Banzai.

Speaker: rachel
Dialogue: Come on--let's parole 'em.

Speaker: rachel
Dialogue: Decided to wake up and see what home looks like, huh?

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: Ellie, you heard your m---

Speaker: ellie
Dialogue: Wh--

Speaker: ellie
Dialogue: Hurrts! It hurrrrts!

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: Anyone who can scream that loud isn't ready for intensive care just yet-- looks like she just skinned her knee.

Speaker: gage
Dialogue: Hi-Durch!

Speaker: church
Dialogue: Waow!

Speaker: gage
Dialogue: Druck!

Speaker: rachel
Dialogue: Gage's gone!

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: Jesus, the road!

Speaker: gage
Dialogue: Drucks!

Speaker: rachel
Dialogue: Gage!

Speaker: rachel
Dialogue: Thank you. Thank you so much.

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: Yes--thanks. I'm Louis Creed.

Speaker: jud
Dialogue: Jud Crandall. I live just across the road.

Speaker: rachel
Dialogue: I'm Rachel. Thanks again for saving the wandering minstrel boy, here.

Speaker: jud
Dialogue: No harm, no foul. But you want to watch out for that road. Those damn trucks go back and forth all day and most of the night.

Speaker: jud
Dialogue: Who might you be, little Miss?

Speaker: ellie
Dialogue: I'm Ellen Creed and I live at 642 Alden Lane, Dearborn, Michigan.  At least, I used to.

Speaker: jud
Dialogue: And now you live on Route 9 in Ludlow, and your dad's gonna be the new doctor up to the college, I hear, and I think you're going to be just as happy as a clam here, Ellen Creed.

Speaker: rachel
Dialogue: Excuse me, Mr. Crandall--I've got to change this kid. It's nice to meet you.

Speaker: jud
Dialogue: Same here. Come over and visit when you get the chance.

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: No-I guess not.

Speaker: ellie
Dialogue: Yayyy!

Speaker: jud
Dialogue: House has stood empty for too long. It's damn good to see people in it again.

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: Hey--they actually found the place!

Speaker: jud
Dialogue: Movin' in's mighty thirsty work. I usually sit out on my porch of an evening and pour a couple of beers over m'dinner. Come on over and join me, if you want.

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: Well, maybe I----

Speaker: first mover
Dialogue: You Mr. Creed?

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: Yes. Just a second.

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: The movers--

Speaker: rachel
Dialogue: Yes--I know. This path, Louis? Where does it go?

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: I don't have the slightest idea. When I saw the house, this field was under four feet of snow.

Speaker: jud
Dialogue: Oh, ayuh! I know. It's a good story, and a good walk, too. I'll take you up there sometime, and tell you the story, too-- after you get settled in.

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: Great.

Speaker: rachel
Dialogue: You're not really going over to have a beer with that old guy, are you?

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: Well, I've got a million questions about the area, and---

Speaker: rachel
Dialogue: ---and you'll end up doing a free consultation on his arthritis or urinary problems and---

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: Did you see his shirt?

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: I really do have a million questions about the area...but the thing I'm really curious about is how come this octogenarian Yankee is decorating the slumped remains of his pecs with the Boss.

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: It's me.

Speaker: jud
Dialogue: Well, come on up and have a beer.

Speaker: jud
Dialogue: You need a glass?

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: Not at all.

Speaker: jud
Dialogue: Good for you.

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: God, that's fine.

Speaker: jud
Dialogue: Ain't it just? The man who invented beer, Louis, that man was having a prime day for himself.

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: What were you listening to?

Speaker: jud
Dialogue: Allman Brothers.

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: jud
Dialogue: The Eat A Peach album. God, they were good before drugs and bad luck caught up with them. Listen to this, Louis.

Speaker: jud
Dialogue: I'm sorry. Wait.

Speaker: jud
Dialogue: Try that.

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: Nice.

Speaker: jud
Dialogue: I like rock and roll. No...I guess that's too mild. I love it. Since my ears started to die out on me, it's the only music I can really hear. And since my wife died...I dunno, some- times a little rock and roll fills up night. Not always, but sometimes.  One more time--welcome to Ludlow. Hope your time here will be a happy one.

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: The one that goes into the woods--sure.

Speaker: jud
Dialogue: That road--and those Orinco trucks-- are the two main reasons it's there.

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: What's at the end of it?

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: And yours.

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: Church! God, you scared the life out of me!

Speaker: church
Dialogue: Waow!

Speaker: jud
Dialogue: Take a look behind you.

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: My God!

Speaker: rachel
Dialogue: It's beautiful!

Speaker: jud
Dialogue: You folks ready to go on?

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: Sure.

Speaker: ellie
Dialogue: But where are we going, Mr. Crandall?

Speaker: jud
Dialogue: You'll see soon enough, hon.

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: Who owns the woods up ahead? Paper companies?

Speaker: jud
Dialogue: Nope. The Micmac Indians. What's up ahead is all that's left of their tribal lands.

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: Not yet...how much further is it?

Speaker: jud
Dialogue: Aw, you'll be okay. Less than a mile.

Speaker: ellie
Dialogue: What's it say, mommy?

Speaker: rachel
Dialogue: It says Pet Cemetery, hon. It's misspelled, but...that's what it says.

Speaker: rachel
Dialogue: Ellen--!

Speaker: jud
Dialogue: I told you it was a bad road, Louis--it's killed a lot of pets and made a lot of kids unhappy. But at least something good come of it. This place.

Speaker: rachel
Dialogue: How can you call it a good thing? A graveyard for pets killed in the road! Built and maintained by broken- hearted children!

Speaker: jud
Dialogue: Well, but Missus Creed! It ain't quite that way, deah!

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: I think it's rather extraordinary.

Speaker: rachel
Dialogue: Extraordinarily morbid, maybe.

Speaker: jud
Dialogue: Well...they have to learn about death somehow, now don't they, Missus Creed? The little ones?

Speaker: jud
Dialogue: Well...well, because--

Speaker: ellie
Dialogue: It's okay, Mr. Crandall--

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: Have you got a death-wish, Ellen?

Speaker: ellie
Dialogue: Well, I thought it was safe--

Speaker: jud
Dialogue: Best never to go climbing on old blowdowns like this, Ellie--sometimes they bite.

Speaker: ellie
Dialogue: Bite?

Speaker: jud
Dialogue: Ayuh.

Speaker: ellie
Dialogue: I want to look around, daddy-- may I?

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: For a little while.

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: I can hardly read these.

Speaker: jud
Dialogue: Ayuh--they get older as you go toward the middle.  Missy Ellen! Come over here just a minute!

Speaker: jud
Dialogue: I see you're quite a reader for such a little girl. Can you read that?

Speaker: ellen
Dialogue: "Spot a good fellow we love you boy."  "Owned by Judson...Judson..." Gee, I can't read the rest.

Speaker: jud
Dialogue: Last name's Crandall, little missy.

Speaker: jud
Dialogue: That's where I buried my dog Spot when he died of old age in 19 and 14. Dug it good and deep. By the time I finished, I had blisters all over my hands and a hell of a crick in my back. Soil's stony up here.

Speaker: jud
Dialogue: Do you know what this place is, Ellie? Oh, I know you know it's a boneyard, but a bone ain't nothing and even a whole pile of 'em don't amount to much. Do you know what a graveyard really is?

Speaker: ellie
Dialogue: Well...I guess not.

Speaker: jud
Dialogue: It's a place where the dead speak, Missy.

Speaker: jud
Dialogue: No--not right out loud. Their stones speak...or their markers. Even if the marker ain't nothing but a tin can someone wrote on with a Magic Marker, it speaks. Ain't that so, Louis?

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: I think it is so, Ellie.

Speaker: ellie
Dialogue: What if you can't read what's written on there anymore?

Speaker: jud
Dialogue: Well, it still says some animal got laid down here after, don't it?

Speaker: ellie
Dialogue: Yes--

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: And that someone cared enough about that animal to mark the spot.

Speaker: ellie
Dialogue: To remember.

Speaker: ellie
Dialogue: Mommy! This is a place where dead animals talk! Mr. Crandall said so!

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: My wife is not crazy about cemeteries of any kind. As you may have noticed.

Speaker: jud
Dialogue: Me neither. But I believe in knowing your enemy.

Speaker: ellie
Dialogue: Daddy, that Pet Sematary is there because of the road, isn't it?

Speaker: ellie
Dialogue: That's what I think. I heard Missy Dandridge tell Mom when Church was fixed he wouldn't cross the road so much.

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: Well, it's always better to take precautions--but I'm sure Church will be all right, honey...

Speaker: ellie
Dialogue: In the end he's gonna croak, isn't he?

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: Lovey...Church might be still alive when you're in a high school...and that's a very long time.

Speaker: ellie
Dialogue: It doesn't seem long to me. It seems short. I think the whole thing about pets dying s-s-sucks!

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: If it was up to me I'd let Church live to be a hundred...but I don't make up the rules.

Speaker: rachel
Dialogue: She's finally asleep.

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: She was a little over-excited, that's all. Poor kid.

Speaker: rachel
Dialogue: It was that place. That creepy cemetery up in the woods. Whatever disease the kids in this town have got, I don't want Ellie to catch it.

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: Jesus, Rachel, what's got into you?

Speaker: rachel
Dialogue: Do you think I didn't hear her tonight, crying as if her heart would break? Here she is thinking Church is going to die.

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: Rachel...someday Church is going to die.

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: Rachel--!

Speaker: ellie
Dialogue: Yee-uck! Gross!

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: He can't help it, babe. Emily Post is going to be beyond him for a few years.

Speaker: ellie
Dialogue: I don't want him to get his nuts cut, daddy! What if he dies?

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: Good God! Where'd you hear that?

Speaker: ellie
Dialogue: Missy Dandridge. And she says it's a operation!

Speaker: rachel
Dialogue: Honey, Church will be fine.

Speaker: ellie
Dialogue: But what if he dies and has to go to the Pet Sematary?

Speaker: rachel
Dialogue: Don't be silly. Church is not going to die.

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: According to what Mr. Crandall says, the road's a lot more dangerous than the operation. Church will be just the same. Well--almost the same--and we won't have to worry about him getting turned into catburgers by one of those damn Orinco trucks.

Speaker: rachel
Dialogue: That's enough of that kind of talk!

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: I just said--

Speaker: rachel
Dialogue: I know what you just said. Ellie, clear your place.

Speaker: rachel
Dialogue: You'll be fine, Ellie. Now you can be excused. Go and wash your face.

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: And Church will be fine.

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: Well, honey...you know that...

Speaker: rachel
Dialogue: Don't shilly-shally, Louis. Give the little girl her promise.

Speaker: ellie
Dialogue: Yayyyy!

Speaker: rachel
Dialogue: Thank you, Louis.

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: Oh, you're welcome. Only if some- thing should go wrong while he's under the gas--it's a one-in-a-thousand shot, but it happens--you explain to her.

Speaker: rachel
Dialogue: Have a great day!

Speaker: gage
Dialogue: Bye-bye!

Speaker: missy
Dialogue: Gonna get his--

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: --nuts cut, yes. Thank you, Missy, for introducing that colorful phrase into my daughter's vocabulary.

Speaker: missy
Dialogue: Don't mention it.

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: You ought to see a doctor about it.

Speaker: missy
Dialogue: It'll pass. They always do.

Speaker: rachel
Dialogue: Thank God. I was a little worried there. Have a great first day at school, doc. No broken bones.

Speaker: charlton
Dialogue: Holy Jesus.  Steve! Steve! Dr. Creed! Dr. Creed, we've got a mess here! Stat!

Speaker: girl
Dialogue: Vic! Vic! Oh Christ! Vic!

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: Steve, get the ambulance over here right now. He's got to go to EMMC.

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: The ambulance is at Sonny's Sunoco downtown, getting--

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: --a new muffler, oh shit--

Speaker: candystriper
Dialogue: I can't look at it...I can't stand it...

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: Help me hold him.

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: It wouldn't matter if we did have the ambulance.

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: It wouldn't matter if we had the SST.

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: He's going. Steve, go call the motor- pool. Marcy, roll out the crash wagon.

Speaker: charlton
Dialogue: It won't--

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: I know it won't! But let's for God's sake do it by the rules!

Speaker: lois
Dialogue: There wasn't even supposed to be a sprain today, my friend--that's what I told her.

Speaker: pascow
Dialogue: ...Pet Sematary...

Speaker: pascow
Dialogue: It's not the real cemetery...  The soil of a man's heart is stonier, Louis...a man grows what he can...and tends it.

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: How do you know my name?

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: Louis, they're sending a--

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: Steve, will you get a sheet to cover him with?

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: He said my name. I heard it. He said my name.

Speaker: pascow
Dialogue: Come on, doc. We got places to go.

Speaker: pascow
Dialogue: Come on, doc--don't make me tell you twice.

Speaker: pascow
Dialogue: Let's go, doc.

Speaker: pascow
Dialogue: Who said you were dreaming?

Speaker: pascow
Dialogue: This is the place where the dead speak.

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: I want to wake up. I want to wake up, that's all. I--

Speaker: pascow
Dialogue: The door must not be opened. The barrier must not be crossed. Don't go on, doc. No matter how much you feel you have to. There's more power here than you know.

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: Please, I want to wake up. Leave me alone. It's not my fault you died; you were as good as dead when they brought you in--

Speaker: pascow
Dialogue: The power of this place is old and always restless. Sometimes the dead do more than speak. Remember, doc.

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: Leave me alone!

Speaker: pascow
Dialogue: Remember.

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: Getting there.

Speaker: rachel
Dialogue: I got eggs down here!

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: Good d--

Speaker: jud
Dialogue: Did you tell me Rachel took the kids back to Chicago for a few days?

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: For Ellie's birthday, yes. I didn't go because her old man thinks I'm a shit and the feeling is heartily re- ciprocated...they'll be back tomorrow night. Jud, what's this about?

Speaker: jud
Dialogue: Well, there's a dead cat over here on the edge of my lawn, Louis. I think it might be your daughter's.

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: Church? Oh. Oh, Jesus.

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: It's Church.

Speaker: jud
Dialogue: I'm sorry. At least it don't look like he suffered.

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: Ellie will, though. She'll suffer plenty.

Speaker: jud
Dialogue: Loved that cat pretty well, didn't she?

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: Bagged cat. What a mess.

Speaker: jud
Dialogue: You going to bury him in the Pet Sematary?

Speaker: jud
Dialogue: Going to tell Ellie?

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: I don't know.

Speaker: jud
Dialogue: Seems like you told me about a promise you made--

Speaker: jud
Dialogue: Cat's just as dead, Louis.

Speaker: jud
Dialogue: No need to apologize.

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: Maybe when they call I'll just tell Ellie I haven't seen the damn cat around. You know?

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: Jud, this is crazy. It's going to be almost dark before we get back.

Speaker: jud
Dialogue: It's going to be dark before we even get where we're going, Louis. But we can do it...and we're going to.

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: But--

Speaker: jud
Dialogue: Does she love the cat?

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: Yes, but--

Speaker: jud
Dialogue: Then come on.

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: Well, folks, here we are, in Louis Creed Dreamland.

Speaker: jud
Dialogue: What say, Louis?

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: Nothing.  Do we plant him on the outer circle or start a new one?

Speaker: jud
Dialogue: We're still not where we're going.

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: What do you mean?

Speaker: jud
Dialogue: The place we're going is on the other side of that.

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: We can't climb over that. We'll break our necks!

Speaker: jud
Dialogue: No. We won't. I have climbed it a time or two before, and I know all the places to step. Just follow me...move easy...don't look down...and don't stop. If you stop, you'll crash through for sure.

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: I'm not climbing that.

Speaker: jud
Dialogue: Give me the cat. I'll take care of it myself.

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: Let's go.

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: God, this is amazing!

Speaker: jud
Dialogue: Just don't stop and--

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: And don't look down. Right.

Speaker: jud
Dialogue: Louis! You all right?

Speaker: jud
Dialogue: No, you shouldn't have stopped. But you got away with it. Important thing is are you sure you're all right?

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: Yes.  Where are we going, Jud?

Speaker: jud
Dialogue: You'll see before long. Let's go.

Speaker: jud
Dialogue: This next bit's like the deadfall, Louis-- you got to walk steady and easy. Just follow me and don't look down.

Speaker: jud
Dialogue: Micmacs used to call it Little God Swamp.

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: Is there quicksand?

Speaker: jud
Dialogue: Ayuh.

Speaker: jud
Dialogue: Ayuh.

Speaker: jud
Dialogue: There's a lot of funny things down this way, Louis.

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: You're telling me.

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: It's funny, all right.

Speaker: jud
Dialogue: Just don't stop, Louis. You don't ever want to stop down here in Little God.  And you don't ever want to look behind you, whatever you hear.

Speaker: jud
Dialogue: Almost there, Louis.

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: You keep saying that.

Speaker: jud
Dialogue: This time I mean it.

Speaker: jud
Dialogue: This was their burying ground, Louis.

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: Whose burying ground?

Speaker: jud
Dialogue: The Micmac Indians. I brought you here to bury Ellen's cat.

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: Why? For God's sake, why?

Speaker: jud
Dialogue: I had my reasons, Louis. We'll talk later. All right?

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: I guess so...but...

Speaker: jud
Dialogue: You want to rest a bit before you start?

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: No, I'm okay. Will I really be able to dig him a grave? The soil looks thin.

Speaker: jud
Dialogue: Soil's thin, all right. But you'll manage.

Speaker: jud
Dialogue: I'm going to sit over yonder and have a smoke. I'd help you, but you've got to do it yourself. Each buries his own. That's how it was done then.

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: You think so?

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: What are those for?

Speaker: jud
Dialogue: Your cairn.

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: Doesn't look like they last long.

Speaker: jud
Dialogue: Don't worry about that.

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: Jud, why am I doing all this?

Speaker: jud
Dialogue: Because it's right.

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: Pax vobiscum, Church old buddy. You were a hell of a god cat. I doubt if you were worth all this aggravation, but you were a hell of a good cat.

Speaker: jud
Dialogue: That's fine. You did real good.

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: Oh, shit! Rachel!

Speaker: jud
Dialogue: When you talk to 'em, not one word about what we done tonight. 'S'far's you know, the cat's still fine.

Speaker: jud
Dialogue: You'll understand. In the meantime, keep your peace. What we did, Louis, was a secret thing. Women are supposed to be the ones who are good at keeping secrets, but any woman who knows anything at all would tell you she's never seen into a man's heart. The soil of a man's heart is stonier, Louis--like the soil up there in the old Micmac burying ground. A man grows what he can...and tends it.

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: But--

Speaker: jud
Dialogue: No buts! Accept what's done, Louis. What we done was right. Another time it might not be, but tonight it was... at least I hope to Christ it was. Now you make your call...but not a word about tonight.

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: Hi, Dory...it's Louis--

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: That'd be real fine.

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: Yeah, I know...how are things out there in Chicagoland?

Speaker: ellie
Dialogue: Fine...except when Mom was airing Gage's diaper rash, he walked away and got into Grampa's study and pooped in Grampa's favorite chair.

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: I said that's too bad. What did you get for presents from Gramma and Grampa?

Speaker: ellie
Dialogue: ...and a Garfield radio! How's Church, dad? Does he miss me?

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: Well...I guess he's just fine, Ellie. I haven't seen him this evening, but--

Speaker: ellie
Dialogue: Well, make sure you put him down cellar before you go to bed so he can't run out in the road and get greased. And kiss him goodnight for me.

Speaker: ellie
Dialogue: Want to talk to Gage?

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: Food, Church...food!

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: Come on, Church! Chow down!

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: In a second.

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: Chewed his way out. Jesus Baldheaded Christ, he ch--

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: Ow!

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: What did we do?

Speaker: jud
Dialogue: I most generally don't start before noon, but this looks like an exception.

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: What did we do, Jud?

Speaker: jud
Dialogue: Why, saved a little girl from being unhappy...that's all. Drink up, Louis!

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: I tried to tell myself I buried him alive. You know--Edgar Allan Poe meets Felix the Cat. But...

Speaker: jud
Dialogue: Wouldn't wash?

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: No. I'm a doctor. I know death when I see it, and Church was dead. He smells horrible and he uses his claws, but he's alive...and I feel like I'm going crazy. It was that place, wasn't it?

Speaker: jud
Dialogue: Ayuh. It was the rag-man told me about the place--Stanley Bouchard. Us kids just called him Stanny B. He was half Micmac himself.

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: Can I have another one?

Speaker: jud
Dialogue: I guess it wouldn't hurt.

Speaker: jud
Dialogue: The Micmacs used to bury their dead up there long before the whites came.

Speaker: jud
Dialogue: They buried their dead and for a long time their dead stayed buried. Then something happened. Half the tribe died in a season. The rest moved on. They said a Wendigo had soured the ground.

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: Wendigo?

Speaker: jud
Dialogue: Spirit of the north country. Not a good spirit. Wendigos are great liars and tricksters, according to the stories. And if one touches you...

Speaker: jud
Dialogue: Maybe it really was a Wendigo-- I ain't the one to say it wasn't-- or maybe it was just some disease. Whatever the reason, those that were left moved on. But they left that place...the way it is now.

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: You and this old Indian rag-man--

Speaker: jud
Dialogue: Stanny B. did for me what I did for you last night, Louis. Only I wasn't alone when Spot came back.

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: How did your mother take it, Jud? How did she take it when your dog came back from the dead?

Speaker: jud
Dialogue: Well, she was a little upset at first, and that's why I thought you ought to hold your peace when you talked to your people last night...you did, didn't you, Louis?

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: jud
Dialogue: Why, then, things should be fine.

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: A little upset is all she was? Because I'll tell you, Jud, my brains feel a little like a nuclear reactor on the edge of a meltdown.

Speaker: jud
Dialogue: She got used to the idea. Spot lived another four years. He died peacefully in the night that second time, and I buried him in the Pet Sematary...where his bones still lie.

Speaker: jud
Dialogue: A man doesn't always know why he does things, Louis. I think I did it because your daughter ain't ready for her favorite pet to die.

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: jud
Dialogue: Ellie's a little scared of death. And the main reason Ellie's that way is because your wife is a lot scared of death. Now you just go ahead and tell me I'm wrong.

Speaker: rachel
Dialogue: Don't shilly-shally, Louis. Give the little girl her promise.

Speaker: pascow
Dialogue: The door must not be opened. The barrier must not be crossed.

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: You don't understand--

Speaker: pascow
Dialogue: Sometimes the dead do more than speak. Remember, doc.

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: Promise...

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: How the hell did you get in?

Speaker: ellie
Dialogue: Daddy!

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: Hi, sugar!

Speaker: ellie
Dialogue: Daddy, is Church all right?

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: Yes...I guess so. He was sleeping on the front porch when I left.

Speaker: ellie
Dialogue: Cause I had a bad dream about him. I dreamed he got hit by a car and you and Mr. Crandall buried him in the Pet Sematary.

Speaker: ellie
Dialogue: Is he really all right?

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: ellie
Dialogue: Because you promised.

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: I know.

Speaker: rachel
Dialogue: Want to take your son, doc?

Speaker: rachel
Dialogue: Yes--you have to take them to someone who grooms animals, though. I think it's pretty expensive.

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: I've noticed it, too. I'll cough up the money, Ellen.

Speaker: ellie
Dialogue: I hate that smell.

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: Yes--I hate it, too.

Speaker: ellie
Dialogue: They're all turning on their lights! Daddy, why are they all turning on their lights in the middle of the day?

Speaker: jud
Dialogue: They do it to honor the dead, Ellen.

Speaker: ellie
Dialogue: Is that right, dad?

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: Yes. To honor the dead.

Speaker: jud
Dialogue: Rachel not feeling well?

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: Well...a touch of the flu...

Speaker: ellie
Dialogue: She's in bed. She was throwing up. Ever since Mrs. Rogers called and said Missy--

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: That's enough, Ellen.

Speaker: jud
Dialogue: Out of the mouths of babes, Louis.

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: This babe has said enough.

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: Hop in, Ellie.

Speaker: jud
Dialogue: Poor Missy. God, I was sorry to hear. I remember when she was no older'n Ellen there, walking down to the store with her Raggedy Anne doll draggin' behind her in the dust. I don't know why God takes someone like her, who should have a bunch of years still in front of them, and lets an old shit like me just go on and on.

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: My father used to have a saying, Jud-- "God sees the truth, but waits."

Speaker: jud
Dialogue: Ayuh...how is your cat, Louis?

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: It's Ellie's cat.

Speaker: jud
Dialogue: Nope. He's your cat now.

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: Ellie? What's wrong?

Speaker: ellie
Dialogue: No more chocolate chip cookies.

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: Huh?

Speaker: ellie
Dialogue: Missy made the best chocolate chip cookies in the world--even Mom said so. Now there won't be any more because she's gonna be dead forever!

Speaker: newscaster
Dialogue: Bizarre as it may seem, it now seems almost beyond doubt: the dead are returning to eat the living.

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: What's up, sugar?

Speaker: ellie
Dialogue: Daddy, do you think Missy Dandridge went to heaven?

Speaker: ellie
Dialogue: At school Michael McDowell said she was gonna fry in hell. Michael McDowell says all sewersides fry in hell.

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: Well, I think Michael McDowell is so full of shit he probably squeaks when he walks, my dear.

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: But don't you dare say that.

Speaker: ellie
Dialogue: I won't...is Missy in heaven, do you think?

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: I don't know, honey. Different people believe all sorts of different things happen to us when we die. Some believe in heaven or hell. Some think we're born again as little children--

Speaker: ellie
Dialogue: Sure, carnation. Like in that movie you rented, Audrey Rose.

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: Well, it's actually reincarnation, but you get the idea. And some people think we just wink out...like a candle flame when the wind blows hard.

Speaker: ellie
Dialogue: Do you believe that?

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: I think we go on. I'm not sure what happens after we die, but yeah-- I have faith in that.

Speaker: ellie
Dialogue: You believe in it.

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: Oh, faith's a little more than just believing.

Speaker: ellie
Dialogue: I don't get it.

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: Well, here we are, sitting in my chair. Do you think my chair will be here tomorrow?

Speaker: ellie
Dialogue: Yeah, sure.

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: Then you have faith in that. But we don't know it will be; after all, some crazed chair-burglar might break in while we're away and steal it, right?

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: But we plan on that chair. We believe in that chair. And I plan on going on somehow as Louis Creed, after I die. I believe I will.

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: Yes ma'am. Just like I have faith that it is now time for Ellen Creed to get ready for bed. So buzz.

Speaker: ellie
Dialogue: I'm not tired!

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: I'm sure you're not.

Speaker: ellie
Dialogue: Then why do I have to go to bed?

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: Because your mother and I need the rest, sugar. Now buzz.

Speaker: rachel
Dialogue: I heard you tonight.

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: I thought maybe you did. I know you don't approve of the subject being raised--

Speaker: rachel
Dialogue: That's not true. The subject scares me. Because of Zelda.

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: Your sister, I know.

Speaker: rachel
Dialogue: Sometimes you're so good with her, Louis--so straight with her--that you make me ashamed of myself.

Speaker: rachel
Dialogue: I'm sorry I couldn't go with you to Missy's funeral. And that I blew up when we went to that silly animal graveyard.

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: That's forgotten.

Speaker: rachel
Dialogue: Not by me, it isn't. I know how badly I acted, how unfair I was. It's just that I..you know.

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: Yes, I guess I do.

Speaker: rachel
Dialogue: I'm going to try to do better.

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: You're doing fine.

Speaker: gage
Dialogue: Go, dayee!

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: Hey, Gage!

Speaker: gage
Dialogue: Dat?

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: String! You're flying it, Gage--you got the hammer, my man!

Speaker: gage
Dialogue: Gage fline it?

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: Bet your boots. Look--

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: See?

Speaker: gage
Dialogue: Gage fline it!!

Speaker: irwin
Dialogue: You--

Speaker: rachel
Dialogue: Louis! Daddy! Stop it! STOP IT!

Speaker: irwin
Dialogue: How do you like that, you son of a bitch? I should have done it sooner!

Speaker: irwin
Dialogue: How do you like that? How do--

Speaker: marcy
Dialogue: Stop them. Right now.

Speaker: irwin
Dialogue: Come on! I'm ready for ya! I'll take y'apart!

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: Stop it!

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: Stop it! Jesus, what's wrong with you, Louis? It's your son's funeral, not a boxing match!

Speaker: pascow
Dialogue: A man grows what he can...and tends it.

Speaker: ellie
Dialogue: I want to fly it! Can I fly it now, mommy!

Speaker: rachel
Dialogue: In a minute, hon. Let Gage finish his turn.

Speaker: irwin
Dialogue: I don't know what happened to me. Louis, please--

Speaker: ellie
Dialogue: It got away from him! That numb shit!

Speaker: gage
Dialogue: Kite fline too fast!

Speaker: jud
Dialogue: Don't let him go in the road, Louis!

Speaker: jud
Dialogue: Your father-in-law packs a wallop, for an old guy. He and his wife gone back to Chicago?

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: No...squatting out there at the Holiday Inn like a couple of vultures. He really thinks Rachel's going to go back with them. Her and Ellie.

Speaker: jud
Dialogue: Louis--

Speaker: jud
Dialogue: What you got there, Ellie?

Speaker: ellie
Dialogue: I'm going to carry this picture, Mr. Crandall, until God lets Gage come back.

Speaker: jud
Dialogue: Ellie...God doesn't do things like that. I know you loved y'brother, but--

Speaker: ellie
Dialogue: He can if He wants to. He can do anything, just like Inspector Gadget on TV. But I have to keep things ready for him, that's what I think. I've got his picture and I'm going to sit in his chair--

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: Ellie--

Speaker: ellie
Dialogue: And I'm going to eat his breakfast cereal, too, even though it tastes like boogers. And...and...

Speaker: jud
Dialogue: Louis, take care of your little girl...she needs you.

Speaker: ellie
Dialogue: G'night daddy.

Speaker: ellie
Dialogue: God could take it back if He wanted to, couldn't He? If He really, really wanted to? Can I have faith in that?

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: Yes--I suppose you can. Good night, Ellie.

Speaker: jud
Dialogue: I got you a fresh beer out of the fridge, Louis.

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: Jud, I buried my son today and I'm very tired. I wonder if we could just--

Speaker: jud
Dialogue: You're thinking of things best not thought of, Louis.

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: I'm thinking about going to bed.

Speaker: jud
Dialogue: You never asked me if anyone had buried a person up there in the Micmac burying ground--

Speaker: jud
Dialogue: --but I think the thought has crossed your mind.

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: Shit! Look at this mess!

Speaker: jud
Dialogue: Ayuh--it's a mess, all right.

Speaker: jud
Dialogue: I know the Micmacs thought it was a holy place...and then they thought it was a cursed place. That's why they moved on.

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: Because something called a wendigo soured the ground.

Speaker: jud
Dialogue: And because the dead walked.

Speaker: jud
Dialogue: Oh, ayuh. It's been done. What you've been thinking of has been done.

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: I'll bite--what's the bottom of the truth, Jud?

Speaker: jud
Dialogue: Why...that sometimes dead is better. That's all. Sometimes dead is better.

Speaker: jud
Dialogue: It ain't your wife and little girl that's got me worried, Louis.

Speaker: jud
Dialogue: Come on.

Speaker: alan
Dialogue: Oh holy Jesus lookit that.

Speaker: bill
Dialogue: You men get out of here!

Speaker: jud
Dialogue: I heard your boy was killed down Georgia.

Speaker: hannibal
Dialogue: Was it?

Speaker: bill
Dialogue: You see him standing there, don't you? Now get out! Get the Christ off my land!

Speaker: bill
Dialogue: He ain't dead! Give him a day or two and he'll be fine! Don't you say that!

Speaker: jud
Dialogue: Bill, this ain't right--you can see that yourself--

Speaker: jud
Dialogue: God help you, Bill.

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: What happened?

Speaker: jud
Dialogue: Get out, Billy--the place is going up.

Speaker: bill
Dialogue: I seen you! I seen you, Jud Crandall!

Speaker: alan
Dialogue: You think Bill's gonna get out, Jud?

Speaker: timmy
Dialogue: LOVE DEAD! HATE LIVING!

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: You better get going, hon.

Speaker: rachel
Dialogue: Oh Louis, I just don't know about this--

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: I told you last night--this can be the start of patching things up with your folks. If something good doesn't come of Gage's death, I think I'll go crazy.

Speaker: rachel
Dialogue: Louis, are you sure?

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: I'm sure.

Speaker: ellie
Dialogue: I don't want to go to Chicago, Gramma Dory.

Speaker: dory
Dialogue: Why not, darling?

Speaker: ellie
Dialogue: I had a bad dream last night. A nightmare.

Speaker: ellie
Dialogue: About Daddy.  And Gage.

Speaker: ellie
Dialogue: And someone named Paxcow.

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: Come on, you guys--before you miss the boat.

Speaker: irwin
Dialogue: Louis, I am sorry. What can I say? That I lost my mind? It's the truth, but no good excuse.

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: Be good to your mother, darlin'. She needs you.

Speaker: ellie
Dialogue: Come with us, daddy. Please come with us!

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: I'll be there in three days--four at the most. I've got to get the electricity shut off and square things with your school so the truant officer ain't after you, and--

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: Of what?

Speaker: ellie
Dialogue: Do you swear?

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: I swear.

Speaker: clerk
Dialogue: Anything else for you today?

Speaker: clerk
Dialogue: Looks like heavy work.

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: It could be.

Speaker: ellie
Dialogue: Paxcow says it's almost too late!

Speaker: rachel
Dialogue: Ellie...Ellie...what...

Speaker: ellie
Dialogue: Paxcow says it's almost too late! We have to go back! Paxcow says it's almost too late!

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: It's wrong.  What happened to you is wrong.

Speaker: pascow
Dialogue: The barrier was not meant to be crossed. The ground is sour.

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: I'll tell you where the ground is sour--the ground in my heart is sour. Let me tell you something else, Vic-baby: Wrong is wrong.

Speaker: pascow
Dialogue: Timmy Baterman. That was wrong.

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: Don't talk like an asshole even if you are just a bit of underdone potato or a blot of mustard.

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: If it doesn't work--if he comes back like Timmy Baterman--I'll put him to sleep. But I'm going to try.  And if it doesn't work...they don't ever need to know.

Speaker: ellie
Dialogue: Paxcow says Daddy's going to do something really bad. He--

Speaker: rachel
Dialogue: Who is this Paxcow? Is he like the boogeyman?

Speaker: ellie
Dialogue: He's a ghost. But he's a good ghost.

Speaker: rachel
Dialogue: There are no ghosts, Ellie. I want you to go to sleep and forget all this nonsense.

Speaker: ellie
Dialogue: Will you at least call and make sure daddy's okay?

Speaker: rachel
Dialogue: Of course I will.

Speaker: rachel
Dialogue: Now will you try to go to sleep?

Speaker: pascow
Dialogue: Pascow.

Speaker: rachel
Dialogue: Pascow? Was she saying Pascow?

Speaker: rachel
Dialogue: He's not home.

Speaker: dory
Dialogue: Why, he probably went out for a hamburger or a chicken dinner, dear. You know how men are when they're alone.

Speaker: rachel
Dialogue: It's Rachel Creed, Jud. I'm calling from Chicago.

Speaker: rachel
Dialogue: No...we're going to be here awhile, and he wanted a few days to wind up our affairs there. I just wondered if he was with you.

Speaker: jud
Dialogue: No--but if he drops by, I'll tell him to call you.

Speaker: rachel
Dialogue: Jud, do you remember the name of the student that died on Louis's first day at work? The one that was hit by a car?

Speaker: rachel
Dialogue: Was it Pascow?

Speaker: jud
Dialogue: Ayuh, I think 'twas. If I see Louis come home before I go to bed, I'll tell him to--

Speaker: rachel
Dialogue: Don't bother. I'm coming home.

Speaker: rachel
Dialogue: Thank you, Jud. Goodbye.

Speaker: jud
Dialogue: No! Rachel! Don't do that! Rachel--!

Speaker: dory
Dialogue: Rachel...darling...you're upset... a night's sleep...

Speaker: rachel
Dialogue: I have to go. The connections are tight, and I have to be at O'Hare in forty minutes. Will you drive me, daddy?

Speaker: irwin
Dialogue: You know something's wrong, don't you? You know. And Ellie does, too.

Speaker: rachel
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: irwin
Dialogue: I'll drive you.

Speaker: ellie
Dialogue: Please hurry.

Speaker: rachel
Dialogue: I will. Come and kiss me.

Speaker: irwin
Dialogue: I'll come with you if you want, honey.

Speaker: jud
Dialogue: You done it, you stupid old man... now you got to undo it.

Speaker: seatmate
Dialogue: Think you'll make your connection in Boston?

Speaker: rachel
Dialogue: I have to.

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: Oh, Gage--oh, honey.

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: It's going to be all right...I swear it's going to be all right...

Speaker: cop
Dialogue: I ain't afraid of no ghost.

Speaker: pascow
Dialogue: There's just time. If you run.

Speaker: pascow
Dialogue: Don't do that, babe.

Speaker: rachel
Dialogue: Make it come back!

Speaker: pascow
Dialogue: You're doing just fine.

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: Please God--let this work.

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: Ain't gonna stop, Gage. Ain't gonna look down.

Speaker: hertz clerk
Dialogue: I'm sorry...it's been very busy tonight. I really don't have anything.

Speaker: pascow
Dialogue: What about the Aries K with the scratch on the side?

Speaker: clerk
Dialogue: I do have an Aries K, but it came in sort of beat up--there's a long scrape up one side--

Speaker: rachel
Dialogue: I'll take it.

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: See? Just imagination. Just--

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: Nothing...there.

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: It was the Wendigo. Dear God, I think the Wendigo just passed within sixty feet of me.

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: It doesn't matter. Come on, Gage.

Speaker: rachel
Dialogue: Now what?

Speaker: pascow
Dialogue: It's trying to stop you. Do you hear me? It's trying to stop you.

Speaker: rachel
Dialogue: Is anyone there?

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: Come back to me, Gage. Come back to us.

Speaker: driver
Dialogue: Hop in, baby.

Speaker: rachel
Dialogue: Thank you.

Speaker: rachel
Dialogue: Can't you go any faster?

Speaker: trucker
Dialogue: Lady, I got nine points on my license right now.

Speaker: rachel
Dialogue: I understand. It's just that--

Speaker: rachel
Dialogue: Thank you. If you only understood how important this is--

Speaker: trucker
Dialogue: That's all right, babe. Only if we get stopped, next time I'll be the one hitchin' and you can give me a ride.

Speaker: jud
Dialogue: Come on, stop playing games!

Speaker: jud
Dialogue: Gage?  Are you the one playing games?

Speaker: jud
Dialogue: Gage? Come on out.

Speaker: jud
Dialogue: I want to show you something.

Speaker: rachel
Dialogue: Thank you so much.

Speaker: trucker
Dialogue: I didn't get a ticket, so you're welcome, lady.  Whatever your problems are, I hope they work out.

Speaker: pascow
Dialogue: It's the end of the line for me, too--I'm not allowed any further.

Speaker: pascow
Dialogue: I'm not.

Speaker: rachel
Dialogue: Who--

Speaker: church
Dialogue: Miaow!

Speaker: rachel
Dialogue: Church!

Speaker: rachel
Dialogue: Gage? Gage?

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: Jesus!

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: Gage--?

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: Oh my God.  Gage!

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: Gage!

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: Hello!

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: Yes, she's fine.

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: She...Rachel's asleep.

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: I'll call you right back.

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: Irwin, you'll just have to--

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: What did you do? What did you--

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: What you buy is what you own, and sooner or later what you own comes home to you. Wasn't that what you said, Jud? Wasn't that pretty much it?

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: Hi, Church. Want some grub?

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: Don't mind me. Eat it while you can. Eat all you want.

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: Eat all you can...all you want... that's right...today's Thanksgiving day for cats, but only if they came back from the dead...

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: No, you don't!

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: Go on. Lie down. Play dead. Be dead.

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: Rachel?  Gage?

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: Gage?

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: All right, Gage...let's.

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: I'm sorry, Jud. I'm so sorry. I'm--

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: I'm going to set things back in order. I...I know just what to do.

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: Gage?

Speaker: gage
Dialogue: No fair! NO FAIR!

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: And what you own always comes home to you.
